Events.eventName: The Field is the World, program, summer 18
Events.description: Reunion program    In August 1986, a box was discovered in the basement of a dorm at Williams College. In it were 64 objects that had been collected a century and a half earlier for the Lyceum of Natural History, a student-run museum on campus from 1835-1909. Among the objects was a Hawaiian kupe’e, or ankle rattle made of dog teeth. The kupe’e inspired a two-part exhibition that surfaces the complex and under-known historical relationship between Williams College and the kingdom of Hawai’i, from the founding of the missionary movement in 1806, to the overthrow of the Hawaiian government in 1893. Drawing on various campus collections and rich archival holdings, the exhibition frames questions about visible and invisible institutional histories, histories of pedagogy and of museum practice, and the impulse to collect and its relationship to agency in the making of histories. Drawing on various campus collections, the exhibition frames questions about visible and invisible institutional histories, museum practice, and the impulse to collect.  Join museum staff to intimately explore these objects behind the scenes, and learn more about this project in process.  This program has capacity for 30 participants.

Co-presented by the Art Department and the Lecture Committee in partnership with WCMA. Jack Whitten (b. 1939) began his earliest experiments in painting during the 1960s by creating dynamic works inspired by Abstract Expressionism. His work of this period manifests emotionally complex meditations on sociopolitical events that shpaed his own understanding of life: Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.'s legacy, the Civil Rights movement, and the Vietnam War among them. A retrospective on Whitten's 50-year long career is currently on view at the Walker Art Center in minneapolis, MN.   Meeting in L231

Events.eventName: Building Themes: Art and Architecture at Williams
Events.description: From the Prendergast Lectures Topics in American Art. Symposium explored the many ways in which art and architecture intersect in the context of Williams College. Two of the talks focused on architecture that houses art: the new W.L.S. Spencer Studio Art Building and Lawrence Hall, home of the Williams College Museum of Art and the Art Department. The other two talks turned the tables and showed how paintings encompass architecture: the Italian watercolors of Louis Kahn and Edward Hopper's treatment of architecture as metaphor. All four challenge the false boundaries that traditionally divide the expressive nature of art from that of architecture.

Panelists from seven academic departments and the Williams College Museum of Art addressed issues of modernism they had previously confronted in their disciplines in general and their own research in particular. The resulting dialogue drew on the study of American and European art and literature as well as religion, philosophy, and physics and was opened up to other fields, represented by other professors and curators who served as audience respondents.

Events.eventName: [We Will] Open With You: General Sisters
Events.description: The Pittsburgh based art collective General Sisters initiate an exchange of perspectives and nourishment at WCMA with this celebratory community workshop and conversation series. Rather than host a conventional opening event tied to a specific exhibition, General Sisters will invite the museum to open itself—over and over and over again throughout the year.. (We Will) Open With You is a collaboration with General Sisters, students in the Contemporary Curatorial Workshop of the Williams Graduate Program in the History of Art, and Assistant Professor of Art Pallavi Sen. This project extends General Sisters’ neighborhood practice of opening a General Store in North Braddock, Pennsylvania to the Williams College Museum of Art.
